{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3562670,"name":"Matthew Dupuis","username":"MatthewD","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/matthewd/{size}/225931_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T04:26:38.925Z","cooked":"

Hello everyone,

Our team is using the YAGSL swerve libary for the first time this year and we’re running into an issue with two of our modules (front left and back right). After we drive the robot semi-aggressively to simulate match driving (high-speed movements, sudden stops, and changes in direction), the module angles become misaligned where the front left and back right modules drive in the reverse direction of what they should be (left is right, forward is backward, etc).

If we drive the robot semi-aggressively again, we can get it to “fix” itself and go back to it working correctly. Driving it further will result in the issue starting once again.

Hardware:

Swerve Modules: MK4i
Drive Motors: Kraken X60
Steer Motors: NEO
Encoders: CANcoder

What We’ve Tried:

  1. Adjusting CANcoder Offsets – We initially fixed the flipped modules by correcting offsets, but the issue reappears after driving aggressively. The bevel gears are all facing left when the offsets are recorded.
  2. Checking CANcoder Readings in Phoenix Tuner – The CANcoders appear to report the correct angles and are counter-clockwise positive.
  3. YAGSL’s 8 Steps – We have gone through YAGSL’s recommended 8 steps several times and the issue continues to persist.
  4. Investigating CANcoder Drift – Because the motors are driving exactly the reverse of what they are supposed to, we do not believe that the encoders are drifting.

Code Base and Video:

Please find our code library here: 4688 2025 Code

A video of the issue can be found here: 4688 YAGSL Issue Video

A photo of our encoder values after the issue starts:

IMG_39931920×1440 260 KB

Any help or suggestions would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance!

Are your encoder magnets glued into the shafts on the swerve modules?

They are secured with loctite, yes.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-20T13:07:32.883Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":74,"readers_count":73,"score":54.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":496307,"topic_slug":"yagsl-swerve-modules-losing-alignment-when-driving","display_username":"Matthew Dupuis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":13827,"username":"chadr03","name":"2582","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadr03/{size}/195529_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49010,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead Mentor & Alumni - 4688 Saints Bot | Secondary Teacher"},"post_url":"/t/yagsl-swerve-modules-losing-alignment-when-driving/496307/3","custom_user_title":"Lead Mentor & Alumni - 4688 Saints Bot | Secondary Teacher","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3562874,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T14:07:56.666Z","cooked":"

I think you’re config is incorrect. Mk4i’s normally have the drive and angle motors inverted. You should correct this. Here are some debugging steps.

  1. Set all drive and angle motor inversions to true.
  2. Redo your zero’s with bevels facing to the left (VERY VERY IMPORTANT, PICK A LEFT AND STICK TO IT. IF YOUR BEVELS ARE NOT FACING THE SAME WAY THIS WILL NOT WORK!).
  3. Use direct angle control.
  4. Spin in place on blocks, check all modules are facing the right direction if modules are off think of what you may need to swap to get all of them facing and spinning the right direction by swapping modules around, DO NOT MESS WITH THE INVERSIONS!
  5. Drive straight in blocks, check the spin of your wheels, they should be going the same direction.
  6. Place on ground and drive around, IT MIGHT SPIN OUT!!
  7. If it spins out do the 8 steps
  8. Set your drive controls back, keep in mind your controls may be backwards now, if so multiply the controller axis by -1

As an FYI your current odometry is backwards too. This will fix that but if you did anything that relied on that backwards odometry you will have to redo it.

Thanks for the suggestions. We’ve tried all steps recommended here but the issue is still occuring. It appeared to be fixed on blocks, but once we put it on the ground the issue started happening once again.

One thing we did notice, however, is that the issue occurs in the AdvantageScope simulation even when the robot is not enabled leading us to think it is not a hardware issue. The magnets were also checked and verified to be secure.

Any additional thoughts or suggestions on steps to take would be greatly appreciated.

We had this exact issue. We identified that it was our gyro. I see that your gyro says it is a navx. Is that the correct gyro? Correct Can id?

In simulation and on blocks modules can go backwards but the spin should always be correct

The spin was correct on blocks where it appeared to be working fine. Once we got it on the ground and attempted to spin and drive at the same time, that is when the issue occured again the FL and BR modules would go the wrong direction.
